issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: iOS: Changes to how iOS does require in 2.2 have broken require

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

components.name: Runtime
components.description: Generic bucket for uncategorized runtime issues

fields.description: Russ McMahon stated he had a conversation with the iOS team that indicated a change in the way commonjs paths were handled, requiring them to be absolute. Until about a week ago, all platforms worked with the TiSDK 2.2.0 and Alloy using relative commonjs paths. Now only iOS does not work. Android and Mobileweb continue to operate fine with Alloy.
fields.summary: Alloy does not work with the latest 2.2.0 master of titanium_mobile for iOS

comments.body: The dependency issue has been solved and alloy now functions properly on version 2.2.0 master of titanium_mobile on iOS.
